Hi Uzma,

What do you want to use them for / where do you want to use them?

If you assign a big image to a small image container they should just 
resize when you save the page.

If you want a smaller size then just right-click and save the image 
direct form the live site and then reload that image in the CMS.

You can't directly access the smaller resized versions in the CMS 
(although as mentioned above the CMS should just select the correct 
size / resize the image for you anyway)

The one exception is in blogs or in the body of text, if this is the 
case you'll need to right-click and save the image (on the live site), 
resize it if needed and then reload.

I'm replying to this piecemeal. First instalment:


1. No related photos at all any more?
There were no related photos appearing. This was because the CMS was looking for French-language photo pages (of which we have none). I have amended the code so that it - instead - looks for English-language photo pages. We will need to republish the French section in order for this to take effect on the live site. However, for the meantime you can confirm it's working in the CMS here:
  http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/fr/news/2009/11/le-cio-est-tres-positif-au-sujet-de-l-avancement-des-travaux-de-londres-2012.php


2. Top nav section 'Séjour' is listed as 'Visitier en 2012' in all breadcrumbs for that section
This is an upshot of the fact that it was felt that there was a need to shorten
"Visiter en 2012" to "Séjour" in the top nav. If this means that the whole
section needs to be renamed "Séjour" then ... that is fine, but it's not my call
- in fact it's probably not even your call (as such) but a question for
translatios.com. The question(s) specifically being:
 a) Is it appropriate to entitle the section "Séjour", and for it to appear as
 such in the breadcrumb.
 b) If so, and if it is appropriate, can they undertake to always translate "Visiting in 2012" as "Séjour".

The button is a gif. See:
 http://www.london2012.com/images/presentation/search-blue-on-white.gif.
Can we request a French language gif from you? Presumably saying "Rechercher".

3.2 Your photos
We are unclear what you would like to do with the "Your photos" links. Should
they simply be disabled (they're pointing to English-language pages)


4. http://www.london2012.com/fr/making-it-happen/planning-consultations/index.php Text in body doesn't point out that Greenwich Park and Earl's Court consultation sites are in English only
This is because the English language page contains hard-coded links to pages. i.e. links that have been chosen by directly specifying an entire url in the link-picker (one of which - in fact - is a short url). As such, these links are NOT under content management, so we have no simple way of knowing that we should display an "(en anglais uniquement)" disclaimer. 

If necessary, we can search for other such occurrences, and provide you with a list, so they can be manually fixed. However, I think that this is outside of the immediate scope of the French site. Please correct me if I'm wrong here.


5. http://www.london2012.com/fr/making-it-happen/sustainability/environmental-monitoring/rapports-de-surveillance.php: text doesn't highlight that reports are in english

   http://www.walthamforest.gov.uk/ "Waltham Forest"
   http://www.newham.gov.uk/ "Newham"
then we don't really have a way of knowing whether any particular editorially-chosen external link is in French or English. This might be something that you might want to direct Translations.com to do? i.e. to "Examine any external links and - if they're English-only, then append "(en anglais uniquement)". I hope my description makes sense. Please let me know if not.

More will follow, tomorrow.
